ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This course allows students to select a research topic in any area of twentieth century American history. The emphasis is on developing a strong research process and on producing an excellent article-length paper. The professor allows a great deal of latitude in topic selection. She is extremely knowledgeable and helpful to students across a number of subdisciplines. This course would be useful to almost any student in American history, American studies, andother related disciplines.

I think that this is a great research seminar, and I would absolutely recommend this course to a fellow student. Anyone who wants to learn how to do primary archival historical research with the leadership, support, and encouragement of an expert should take this class.

I would recommend this class to anyone who wants to do a piece of historicalwriting. The course looks at doing history from the inside out. You learn how to think like a historian, how to conceptualize a topic, break it down into little bits, and imagine and describe its wider significance, so the topic can find a place in the historical literature.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I feel like I learned how to do research this semester. The process that Prof. Gilmore outlined for us will be extremely useful to me in my future research projects.Also, the project I worked on might become part of my dissertation--at any rate, it informed my dissertation in allowing me to explore a segment of my topic of interest.
I have learned so much in this class about research and writing. I know that this learning will inform my future projects - both in terms of content and methodology.

The course started my dissertation process and gave me a road map for the next few years. I was able to begin to develop the topic and, just as important, gain an overall view of what books/articles I will need to read and what topics I will need to research.
